questions.question: Which mathematical system is foundational for digital logic design, providing the framework for representing and manipulating logic operations?
options: Calculus
Linear Algebra
Boolean Algebra
Differential Equations
Group Theory

questions.question: In computer architecture, what is the primary role of a "register file" within the Central Processing Unit (CPU)?
options: To manage virtual to physical memory address translation
To coordinate input/output (I/O) operations with peripherals
To store a collection of general-purpose registers for high-speed CPU access to frequently used data and addresses
To execute complex arithmetic and logic operations
To temporarily store microcode instructions before decoding

questions.question: In digital IC design, what does a "Clock Domain Crossing (CDC)" primarily refer to?
options: The physical path a clock signal takes across the silicon die
A synchronization problem arising when data is transferred between circuits operating on different, unsynchronized clock signals
A technique used to measure the propagation delay of a signal through multiple gates
The process of slowing down a clock signal for low-power operation
An architectural decision to use multiple CPUs with entirely separate clocks on an SoC

questions.question: What is the primary goal of Static Timing Analysis (STA) in the digital IC design flow?
options: To verify the functional correctness of the design by simulating all possible input vectors
To generate optimized physical layout data for manufacturing
To ensure that all power and ground connections are robust and sufficient
To determine if the circuit will operate correctly at its target clock frequency under all specified operating conditions (e.g., temperature, voltage)
To create a detailed power consumption report for the entire chip

questions.question: In computer architecture, what is the primary purpose of an "interrupt" mechanism?
options: To initiate the execution of a new program or process
To store temporary data during function calls or context switches
To signal the CPU that an event requiring its immediate attention (e.g., from an I/O device) has occurred, causing it to pause its current task and handle the event
To manage the flow of data between different levels of the memory hierarchy (e.g., cache to main memory)
To allocate physical memory pages to newly created processes
